description: From Middle English also, alswo, alswa (also als(e), as, whence English as), from Old English ealswā (“just like, also”), from Proto-West Germanic *allswā, equivalent to all +‎ so. Cognate with Scots alsa, alswa (“also, even so, in the same way, as, as well”), Saterland Frisian also (“accordingly, therefore, thus”), West Frisian alsa (“so, just so, even so, thus”), Old Saxon alsō (“similarly, as if, just as, when”), Dutch alzo (“so, thus”), German also (“so, thus”), Danish altså (“so”), Norwegian Bokmål altså (“so, therefore, accordingly, thus”), Norwegian Nynorsk altso (“so, accordingly, therefore, thus”), Swedish alltså (“so, therefore, accordingly, thus, then”). Doublet of as. More at all, so.

entries.meaning: (conjunctive, focus) In addition; besides; as well; further; too. [from 14th c.]
examples: Everyone had eggs for breakfast, but Alice also had toast.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To the same degree or extent; so, as.
examples: […]  thereupon the queen's majesty  […]  did send a solemn ambassade of her privy-counsellors, whereof one was an ancient earl of the realm, the other also an ancient baron of the same, and others of the council of her state  […]
